key_points: Lane Luper, formerly first camera assistant on 'Rust,' quit due to safety concerns before the fatal shooting of Halyna Hutchins.
Luper and other crew members had walked off the set in protest of working conditions hours before Hutchins was killed by Alec Baldwin.
He cited lax COVID policies, poor housing situations, and specifically gun safety concerns in his resignation letter.
Baldwin's discharge of a prop gun resulted in the death of Hutchins and injury of director Joel Souza, pausing production.
'Rust' producers deny Luper's claims about ignoring safety concerns and budget issues.
Investigators believe a real bullet was loaded in the firearm Baldwin used.
Assistant director David Halls, who declared the gun 'cold,' claimed ignorance of live rounds in the weapon.
The film's armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, is under scrutiny but denies knowing the source of live rounds.
Three guns and about 500 rounds of ammunition, including live rounds, were found on set.
The Santa Fe District Attorney has not ruled out charges against anyone involved in the incident.
spokespersons: Santa Fe County Sheriff Adan Mendoza
Santa Fe District Attorney Mary Carmack-Altwies
